thread.title: 11 things we'll remember from the Great British Bake Off final 2015
thread.title_full: 11 things we'll remember from the Great British Bake Off final 2015

title: 11 things we'll remember from the Great British Bake Off final 2015
text:
11 things we'll remember from the Great British Bake Off final 2015 11 things we'll remember from the Great British Bake Off final 2015 
Press Association 2014 / / National Entertainment News Share 
So the Great British Bake Off 2015: and what a final. There were nerves, there were disasters, there were even comedy moments. 
Here are 11 things we wonâ€™t forget. 1. Everyone was being dramatic The Great British Bake Offâ€™s Nadiya (Mark Bourdillon/BBC) 
The music is getting faster and faster, icing is being frantically piped, someone is fretting next to an oven: the Great British Bake Off is undeniably dramatic. 
After 10 weeks of challenges, the bakers have reached the final â€“ where a bad bake begins to seem like a life-or-death situation. So you canâ€™t blame them for being a little melodramatic. 
â€œThis could be a pivotal moment in my life, this weekend,â€ Ian said, while Nadiya added: â€œWhatever happens here today I will have to live with for the rest of my life.â€ 
Poor Tamal also went for just a little hyperbole: â€œThis is the worst pastry in the world, ever.â€ 
And Ian moaned: â€œYou do wonder why you put yourself through this, sometimes.â€ 2. But there was camaraderie A little selfie taken at the Final. How far we've come! Hope you enjoy tonight as much as we did filming it. #GBBO pic.twitter.com/DX3nb5GB6u 
â€” TAMAL RAY (@DrRayBakes) October 7, 2015 Promoted stories 
You donâ€™t get to the final without being fiercely competitive â€“ but Nadiya and Tamal in particular have developed a lovely teasing relationship. 
â€œThanks little chum,â€ Tamal said to 4ft 11 Nadiya as she helped him pick his baking implements off the floor. 
And when Nadiya decided not to batch-bake her buns according to Paulâ€™s preferences, he was on hand to jokingly play on her fears: â€œIf you want to break Paulâ€™s rulesâ€¦â€ 3. There were moments of panic When you canâ€™t even bring yourself to look in the oven. #GBBO pic.twitter.com/ibWOWasEFO 
â€” British Bake Off (@BritishBakeOff) September 30, 2015 
It was hard not to feel sorry for Ian when he had the gut wrenching realisation: â€œDid I leave something out?â€ 
Alas for Ian, heâ€™d forgotten to put sugar in his cardamom and cinnamon spiced iced buns with apple and cranberry jam. The mistake didnâ€™t get past Mary and Paul, who quickly found out there was something dreadfully wrong with the buns and pulled disapproving faces. 
It was a forgetful weekend for Ian, who puzzled over his showstopper curry carrot cake mixture â€“ before realising: â€œI forgot to put the oranges in with the mixture!â€ Luckily, it wasnâ€™t too late for a quick fix. 
Our hearts also went out to Tamal, who couldnâ€™t get his creme patissiere to set in time. After lots of anxious checks on his creme pat in the freezer and rising panic, he cut his losses. â€œItâ€™s so frustrating!â€ he complained to Nadiya. 4. And then there was the bun-whispering The Great British Bake Offâ€™s Ian (Love Productions) 
We always knew there was something of the Prince Charles about Ian â€“ but instead of whispering to his plants to encourage them to grow, Ian whispers to his buns to help them rise. 
â€œGood luck little fellasâ€ said Ian to his iced buns. â€œCome on, buns.â€ 5. There were plenty of puns Mel Giedroyc and Nadiya Jamir Hussain (Love Productions/BBC) 
Our favourite pun of the episode cam from Mel, announcing the end of the signature bake: â€œString up the bunting. This bun ting is over.â€ 6. The judges made withering comments The Great British Bake Offâ€™s Mary Berry (Mark Bourdillon/Love Productions) 
And our favourite judgeâ€™s comment was from Mary, on Tamalâ€™s millefeuille: â€œIt looks as though you sat on the top to squash them all in.â€ Ouch. 7. There was also high praise Bake off final here we go !!! pic.twitter.com/YR0tn2lO7F 
â€” Paul Hollywood (@PaulHollywood) October 7, 2015 
When the judges want to be nice, they can be very, very nice. Paul called Ianâ€™s elderflower and lemon iced buns â€œdynamiteâ€, while for Mary they were â€œsheer heaven on a plateâ€. 8. The technical challenge was personalised The Great British Bake Offâ€™s Tamal, with Sue Perkins (Love Productions) 
When Paul and Mary asked the bakers to create rough-puff raspberry millefeulle, it wasnâ€™t an accidental choice. They decided on the challenge because all the finalists have previously struggled with pastry. 
Clever Nadiya didnâ€™t take long to twig: â€œDo you think weâ€™re being tested because we did bad pastry? Itâ€™s a personalised challenge just for us three.â€ 
â€œOh, god, yeah!â€ said Ian, having flashbacks to cream horns and vol-au-vents. 
Nadiya was convinced: â€œIt is, I think it is!â€ 9. Paul Hollywood failed at intimidation Paul Hollywood and Mary Berry (BBC/Love Productions/Tom Dymond) 
At the end of the showstopper challenge, just to make things a bit more stressful for the contestants, Paul and Mary walked around the tent asking intimidating questions. 
â€œHappy, Nadiya?â€ Paul asked menacingly. 
â€œYeah,â€ she said, pausing before mocking him right back: â€œHappy, Paul?â€ 
All Paul could do in reply was giggle. 10. We met the finalistsâ€™ families On the train home to Luton! See you soon mum and baba and the rest of my rowdy brood!!! Missing you abdal! ğŸ˜˜ pic.twitter.com/uPR95zp3NZ 
â€” Nadiya Jamir Hussain (@BegumNadiya) August 20, 2015 
It was time for a peek at the finalistsâ€™ back stories â€“ and to meet their very cute kids. 
Tamalâ€™s big sister was super proud of him. â€œHeâ€™s the full package for me,â€ she said before starting to cry. We also got to look at baby photos: Tamal, it turns out, was a very cute kid. 
â€œMy daddyâ€™s done really well to get to the final,â€ said Ianâ€™s cute blonde daughter, while his wife complained heâ€™d become like a â€œman possessedâ€ in the kitchen. 
â€œHeâ€™s a rock in our family. Iâ€™m very proud of him,â€ she added. 
Nadiyaâ€™s husband was also supportive: â€œSheâ€™s a winner, sheâ€™s a champion in our eyes.â€ 
â€œI like lemon cakes, I like chocolate cakes, I like mud cakes,â€ proclaimed their daughter â€“ which is good, with a mum like Nadiya. 11. And Nadiya won! The Great British Bake Offâ€™s Nadiya (Mark Bourdillon/Love Productions) 
With a first place in the technical challenge, an impressive set of iced buns and a beautiful showstopper wedding cake, Nadiya was on a high. It was her week â€“ and her series â€“ as she was crowned winner of the Great British Bake Off 2015. 
Hurrah! The Great British Bake Off 2015 contestants (Mark Bourdillon/Love Productions) Promoted Stories
